title: Our LLC got eviction notice yesterday
question: We didn't pay rent past a few month and we got the notice. We have no money in an account as company or personal. What would be the next? We signed as personal responsibility, too. We are going to close our company because we have no job and have debt from our vendor. Please advice. Thank you.
answers: Both other attorneys offered good advice. In addition, if you personally or the LLC has nothing in the bank, you may be judgment proof, meaning that even if the landlord obtains a money judgment against you they cannot collect. The judgment will stay on your record and can come back to haunt you if you do start making money later on. You also might want to consider bankruptcy to get rid of the debts and to bring the lawsuit to a halt. Consultations with a bankruptcy attorney are usually free.

I assume you are referring to a commercial lease. If the LLC members personally guaranteed the lease, both the LLC and the individual members will likely be named as defendants in the unlawful detainer lawsuit and/or a breach of lease lawsuit.

Keep in mind that the LLC must be represented by counsel in any litigation. California case law has held that a corporation or LLC cannot represent itself in court, either in propria persona or through an officer or agent who is not an attorney. (Merco Constr. Engineers, Inc. v. Municipal Court (1978) 21 Cal. 3d 724, 729.) See also Van Gundy v. Camelot Resorts, Inc. (1983) 152 Cal.App.3d Supp. 29, 32; Caressa Camille, Inc. v. Alcoholic Beverage Control Appeals Bd. (2002) 99 Cal.App.4th 1094, 1101; citing Merco Constr. Engineers, Inc. v. Municipal Court (1978) 21 Cal.3d 724, 727, 729 and Paradise v. Nowlin (1948) 86 Cal.App.2d 897, 898.

If you have no money in the LLC or personally, the best thing to do would be to move out and surrender possession of the premises. This way, it minimizes the chance that the landlord will sue for more money.

you need to file an answer to the complaint. you can then move out of the premises and they will be required to convert the case to a general civil action. Contact a local lawyer who handles landlord tenant matters. Good luck.
